title: Forget the delivery truck. Walgreens is delivering aspirin, snacks via drone
text:
CLOSE Starting this month, Walgreens customers can purchase items online and have them delivered to their doorstep by drone. Harrison Hill, USA TODAY

Sick on the couch and in need of a cough drop? The kids are home from school, and you've run out of gummy bears and Goldfish crackers?

Walgreens customers in Virginia will now be able to get those items, and many more, dropped at their doorstep – by drone.

The retailer is the first in the nation to deliver purchases on-demand by drone in a pilot program debuting in the city of Christiansburg.

In a partnership with dronemaking company Wing, Walgreens will let customers tap the Wing app and get individual items, such as aspirin or tissues, or choose among six packs containing items for allergies, first aid and other needs. A drone will be dispatched to pick up the items, then travel to the customer's home, delivering the purchases within minutes.

“We are very excited about the partnership and the future of drone delivery,’’ said Vish Sankaran, chief innovation officer for Walgreens Boots Alliance.

Christiansburg was chosen because it is near Virginia Tech, which has collaborated with Wing for three years through the U.S. Department of Transportation's Integration Pilot Program.

Walgreens will pilot drone delivery in Christiansburg, Va., starting in October (Photo: Walgreens/Wing)

Christiansburg residents who want to take part in the pilot can go to wing.com/Virginia for additional information, and Walgreens and Wing will spread the word by demonstrating the service and through other communication venues.

The drone can cover a distance of six miles each way. Walgreens will not be the only retailer whose goods are part of the pilot. Customers will be able to get birthday cards, small gifts and even ice cream from Sugar Magnolia, a regional company.

Wing is teaming up with FedEx to offer drone delivery of packages in certain parts of Christiansburg.

“This trial is intended to demonstrate the benefits of drone delivery by improving access to health care products, creating new avenues of growth for local businesses and exploring ways to enhance last-mile delivery service,’’ Wing CEO James Burgess said.
